definitions: temporarily stopped, delayed, or prevented from continuing normally
hanging down from something above without touching the ground below
consisting of particles mixed throughout a liquid without dissolving
examples: The suspended student must wait three days before returning
All suspended operations will resume next Monday morning
Beautiful suspended lanterns decorated the entire garden pavilion
The suspended bridge swayed gently in the mountain breeze
Suspended particles in the water made it appear cloudy
The suspended sediment slowly settled to the river bottom

definitions: arousing excited expectation or uncertainty about what will happen next
examples: The suspenseful movie kept everyone on the edge of their seats
She writes incredibly suspenseful mystery novels that readers love

definitions: having or showing cautious distrust of someone or something
causing one to have the idea that something is wrong or questionable
examples: The suspicious neighbor watched every visitor through her curtains
Police became suspicious when his story kept changing dramatically
Several suspicious packages were found near the train station
Her suspicious behavior made everyone feel uncomfortable and worried

definitions: able to be maintained at a certain level without depleting natural resources
able to be upheld or defended over a long period of time
examples: Sustainable farming practices help protect our environment for future generations
The company invested heavily in sustainable energy sources last year
This rapid growth rate is not sustainable in the long term
They need a sustainable business model to survive the competition

definitions: continuing for an extended period or without interruption over time
examples: The sustained effort finally paid off after three difficult years
Sustained winds of over sixty miles per hour battered the coast

definitions: having or showing excessive confidence or arrogance in one's appearance or manner
examples: His swagger attitude annoyed everyone at the important meeting
The swagger young executive strutted through the office lobby

definitions: consisting of or resembling a swamp with soft wet ground
examples: The swampy terrain made hiking nearly impossible after the rain
Mosquitoes thrive in these swampy conditions during summer months

definitions: impressively fashionable and expensive in appearance or style
examples: They stayed at a swank hotel overlooking Central Park
The swank restaurant required reservations months in advance

definitions: engaging in daring and romantic adventures with flamboyant confidence and style
examples: The swashbuckling hero rescued the princess from danger
His swashbuckling tales of piracy entertained children for hours

definitions: extending or performed over a wide area affecting many things
having a continuous curved form extending over a wide area
examples: The sweeping changes affected every department in the company
Congress passed sweeping legislation to reform healthcare completely
The sweeping staircase dominated the mansion's grand entrance hall
Her sweeping gesture encompassed the entire mountain range view

definitions: having the pleasant taste characteristic of sugar or honey
having a kind, pleasant, or gentle nature or manner
pleasing to the senses or mind in a gentle agreeable way
examples: The sweet dessert was perfect after our spicy dinner
These sweet strawberries taste better than candy from the store
Your sweet grandmother always remembers everyone's birthday with cards
What a sweet gesture to bring flowers for the host
The sweet scent of roses filled the entire garden
Sweet music drifted through the open windows all evening

definitions: having sugar or another sweetener added to make something sweet
examples: Sweetened condensed milk is essential for this recipe
Many people prefer sweetened tea over the unsweetened version

definitions: being particularly favorable, generous, or advantageous especially in business dealings
examples: The union negotiated a sweetheart deal with management
Critics called it a sweetheart contract favoring the corporation

definitions: very good, excellent, or impressive in quality or appearance
examples: That's a swell idea for the community fundraiser
We had a swell time at the beach yesterday

definitions: increased in size, especially as a result of injury or accumulation
examples: His swelled ankle needed immediate medical attention yesterday
The swelled river threatened to overflow its banks

definitions: having been cleaned or cleared with a broom or brush
examples: The swept floor sparkled in the morning sunlight
A freshly swept porch welcomed all the arriving guests

definitions: moving or capable of moving with great speed or velocity
happening quickly or promptly without delay in time
examples: The swift current carried the boat downstream rapidly
Swift horses were essential for delivering urgent messages
Management promised swift action on the safety concerns
The court delivered swift justice to the convicted criminal

definitions: relating to or used for the activity of swimming in water
examples: She bought new swimming goggles for her training sessions
The swimming instructor taught beginners every Saturday morning

definitions: fashionably lively and exciting with modern entertainment and social activities
examples: London was a swinging city in the nineteen sixties
The swinging nightlife attracted tourists from around the world

definitions: impressively fashionable, elegant, or luxurious in appearance or style
examples: The swish hotel lobby impressed all the visiting dignitaries
She arrived at the swish restaurant wearing designer clothes

definitions: enlarged beyond normal size especially from injury, disease, or fluid retention
examples: Her swollen feet made walking extremely painful and difficult
The swollen river burst through the old wooden dam

definitions: bound by or having taken a formal oath especially in legal contexts
determined and unchangeable in one's attitude especially regarding enemies
examples: The sworn testimony must be completely truthful and accurate
A sworn affidavit accompanied all the legal documents submitted
They had been sworn enemies since their business partnership ended
Despite being sworn rivals, they showed mutual respect professionally

definitions: relating to or consisting of syllables as units of speech sounds
examples: Japanese uses a syllabic writing system called hiragana
The syllabic structure determines the poem's rhythmic pattern

definitions: consisting of or associated with woods and trees in a pleasantly rural setting
examples: The sylvan landscape provided a peaceful retreat from city life
They built their cabin in a sylvan valley near the lake

definitions: involving interaction between two different organisms living in close physical association typically to mutual advantage
examples: Bees and flowers have a symbiotic relationship benefiting both species
The symbiotic partnership between the companies increased their profits

definitions: serving as a symbol or representation of something else especially something abstract
examples: The dove is symbolic of peace throughout many cultures
Her symbolic gesture meant more than any words could express

definitions: having corresponding parts that are the same in size, shape, and position on opposite sides
examples: The symmetric design created perfect visual balance in the room
Symmetric patterns are common in traditional Islamic architectural art

definitions: made up of exactly similar parts facing each other or around an axis
examples: The butterfly's symmetrical wings displayed beautiful matching patterns
Ancient Greek temples featured perfectly symmetrical architectural designs

definitions: feeling, showing, or expressing sympathy and concern for others' misfortunes
showing approval of or favor toward an idea or action
examples: The sympathetic nurse comforted the frightened young patient
She was sympathetic to his problems but couldn't help financially
The judge was sympathetic to their environmental protection arguments
Management proved sympathetic to the workers' reasonable demands

definitions: relating to or having the form or character of a symphony orchestra
examples: The symphonic performance lasted over two hours last night
She composed several symphonic works for the national orchestra

definitions: showing symptoms of a particular disease or medical condition
serving as a symptom or sign characteristic of something larger
examples: Fever is symptomatic of many different infectious diseases
These symptomatic patients require immediate medical evaluation today
This failure is symptomatic of deeper organizational problems
Rising crime rates are symptomatic of social inequality issues

definitions: relating to or involving synapses between nerve cells in the nervous system
examples: Synaptic transmission is crucial for brain function and cognition
The synaptic connections strengthen with repeated use over time

definitions: occurring or operating at the same time or rate in coordination
examples: The synchronised swimmers performed their routine flawlessly together
Perfectly synchronised movements created a stunning visual display

definitions: caused to occur or operate at the same time or rate
examples: The synchronized clocks showed exactly the same time worldwide
Their synchronized efforts produced remarkable results within months

definitions: existing or occurring at the same time in a coordinated way
examples: Synchronous learning requires all students to be online simultaneously
The synchronous motors operate at exactly the same speed

definitions: having a rhythm that stresses beats normally not accented in music
examples: The syncopated rhythm made everyone want to dance immediately
Jazz features heavily syncopated melodies throughout its compositions

definitions: relating to the interaction of elements that produces a combined effect greater than individual parts
examples: The synergistic effect of the drugs enhanced their therapeutic value
Their synergistic partnership produced innovative solutions to complex problems

definitions: having the same or nearly the same meaning as another word
so closely associated with something as to be nearly equivalent
examples: 'Happy' and 'joyful' are synonymous adjectives in English
These synonymous terms can be used interchangeably in writing
His name became synonymous with excellence in scientific research
Silicon Valley is synonymous with technological innovation and startups

definitions: made by chemical synthesis especially to imitate a natural product
not genuine or sincere but produced artificially
examples: Synthetic fabrics are often cheaper than natural materials
The company developed synthetic diamonds for industrial use
Her synthetic enthusiasm fooled no one at the meeting
Critics dismissed his synthetic concern as purely political maneuvering

definitions: done or acting according to a fixed plan or system with methodical procedure
examples: The systematic approach yielded better results than random testing
Police conducted a systematic search of the entire building

definitions: relating to or affecting a system as a whole rather than particular parts
examples: Systemic racism affects all aspects of society and institutions
The patient suffered from systemic infection requiring immediate treatment

definitions: having a grey or brownish coat with dark stripes typical of certain cats
examples: The tabby cat slept peacefully on the sunny windowsill
She adopted a beautiful tabby kitten from the shelter

definitions: prohibited or restricted by social custom making something unacceptable to mention or do
examples: Discussing salary remains taboo in many professional settings
Certain taboo subjects were never mentioned at family dinners

definitions: arranged or displayed in the form of a table with rows and columns
examples: The tabular data made comparisons much easier to understand
Please present the results in tabular format for clarity

definitions: understood or implied without being stated openly or directly in words
examples: Their tacit agreement avoided any need for formal contracts
She gave her tacit approval with a simple nod

definitions: reserved or uncommunicative in speech saying little habitually
examples: The taciturn farmer answered questions with single words only
His taciturn nature made social gatherings uncomfortable for everyone

definitions: slightly sticky to the touch but not fully wet or dry
showing poor taste or quality being cheap and gaudy
examples: The paint was still tacky after four hours of drying
Don't touch the tacky varnish or you'll leave fingerprints
Her tacky decorations embarrassed the more sophisticated guests present
That tacky souvenir shop sells the worst tourist trinkets

definitions: relating to or involving carefully planned actions to achieve a specific military or other goal
examples: The tactical decision to retreat saved many soldiers' lives
Their tactical approach to negotiations secured better terms eventually

definitions: of or connected with the sense of touch or perceived by touching
examples: Children learn through tactile experiences with different textures
The tactile exhibit allowed blind visitors to experience art

definitions: marked or labeled with a tag for identification or information
examples: All tagged items are on sale this weekend only
The tagged photos appeared instantly on social media platforms
